Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Microstructured Sapphire Optical Fiber for SERS Sensing and Measurements at Elevated Temperatures

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective: The objective of this program is to explore an innovative concept that leads to microstructured sapphire fibers with porous, anodized aluminum oxide as cladding that further functions as anchor of Au and Ag nanoparticles for chemical sensing and measurements by surface-enhanced Raman scattering at high temperatures.

Intellectual Merit: The intellectual merit is to theoretically calculate mode-field distribution in the porous aluminum oxide cladding to determine the optimal microstructure of the oxide for high mode-field overlap and thus strong light-analyte interactions; to use the calculated results as a guide to coat and anodize Al coating on sapphire fiber to obtain porous oxide-cladded microstructured sapphire fiber; and to evaluate the feasibility of microstructured sapphire fibers decorated with Ag and Au nanoparticles for SERS measurements of hot combustion gas at 500ยบ-1500ยบC. The program is transformative in that it will help usher in a new category of specialty optical fibers for demanding applications where existing fiber technologies are not suitable.

Broader Impacts: The broader impacts are multi-faceted. Technologically speaking, optically coupled microstructured sapphire fibers could be used as a micro-reactor or test bed for the development and understanding of new catalytic phenomena with laser spectroscopy as a powerful in-situ probing technique. From educational perspective, this program will provide a fertile training ground for a graduate student and a diverse group of undergraduate and high school students. The collaboration with Czech researchers adds a significant international dimension. Dissemination of research results will be achieved via conference presentations and peer-reviewed publications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this EAGER project was two-fold: to explore an innovative concept that entails transformation of aluminum-coated sapphire fiber to microstructured sapphire fiber with anodized aluminum oxide (AAO) cladding of radially aligned pore channels; to demonstrate the use of the resultant microstructured sapphire fiber for evanescent-field chemical sensing using SERS enabled by Ag nanoparticles entrapped in the AAO pore channels. Key accomplishments are as follows: (1) We have used the melt dipping coating method to deposit smooth and uniform Al thin films on sapphire fiber; (2) We have developed the anodization strategy leading to full conversion of the Al coating to AAO of a few microns in thickness, hence “microstructured” sapphire fiber; (3) We have shown that AAO cladding is structurally stable up to 1000oC; (4) We have demonstrated that AAO cladding functions as a host for as well as stabilizer for Ag nanoparticles for high temperature use; and (5) We have shown that “microstructured” sapphire fiber with Ag nanoparticles contained within the cladding pore channels exhibits robust SERS activity after thermal treatment at 500oC.

This project has demonstrated for the first time the feasibility of fabricating microstructured sapphire fiber through a simple and cost-effective growth process of porous AAO from Al coating via anodization. This approach has paved the way towards commercially viable cladding method for sapphire fiber. The porous nature and the ability to tailor the pore size and interpore distance (hence porosity) will open the door to endow sapphire fiber with new optical properties and functionalities for a variety of applications. This project has promoted strong international collaboration with the Institute of Photonics and Electronics, the Academic of Sciences of the Czech Republic. It has also brought Fiberguide Industries, a company that fabricates and markets metal-coated silica fiber sensors, and the Stevens team together to explore research collaboration in metal coating and sensors development. The project has resulted in one peer reviewed publication (Opt. Lett., 39, 5822-5825 (2014)), one manuscript submission (pending at Nature Photonics), one conference presentation (SPIE DSS 2014) and one patent application (US61/977,452).
